Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Morphological Decomposition in Arabic

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
When we hear a word, many factors affect the speed and accuracy with which we decide that what we have heard is indeed a word of our language. Word frequency is a particularly salient predictor of a listener's behavior when presented with a word; words which are more frequent are recognized more quickly than words which are less frequent. Moreover, the frequency of individual word parts such as suffixes and prefixes also have an effect on the recognition of the word as a whole. These phenomena are important for psycholinguistic models of storage and processing which represent how people acquire words of a language, store them in their minds, and retrieve them when they must perceive or produce them. Such models inform effective methods for teaching language as well as diagnosis and treatment of language disorders. However, studies focusing on the role of frequency in word recognition have been largely limited to Indo-European languages, which results in an incomplete picture of the mechanisms which allow humans to learn, recognize and produce language.

The main goal of this psycholinguistic research is to explore the role of frequency in word recognition for a colloquial dialect of Arabic spoken in Amman, Jordan. This research entails psycholinguistic experiments measuring reactions to a variety of kinds of spoken words which differ based on the frequencies of the parts that they contain. Furthermore, these studies involve the collection of personal linguistic histories, as well as the gathering of texts and transcripts from Web, chat, and broadcast domains. This research will contribute to a richer understanding of how Arabic speakers determine what constitutes a word of their dialect, and what properties of the word affect the speed and accuracy with which they do so. Determining which word parts contribute most to their storage and access in the mind will result in more informed ways of teaching colloquial Arabic dialects to non-native speakers. Robust data focusing on which words actually belong to this particular dialect will contribute to dictionary-writing and lexicon-building, strengthening the scarce resources which exist for spoken Arabic dialects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project addressed the question: how are words stored and accessed in the mind of an Arabic speaker? Words of all languages have properties which affect how that word is learned, stored, and ultimately remembered. Word frequency has major implications for several facets of a language. Most importantly, words which are more frequent are recognized more quickly than words which are less frequent, which is important for understanding how people remember words. Second, historically, words which are more frequent are less likely to change their meanings over time when compared to less frequent words, creating an important intersection between word frequency and historical study. As for the teaching of languages, lexicons of highly frequent words are especially efficient for learners of a language when compared to dictionaries of words of varying frequency, thus the study of how frequency and word recognition interact is also important for acquisition of a second language. 


The frequency of the individual morphemes -- stems and affixes -- that make up a word has a less clear role in word storage and retrieval. However, the question of the role of morpheme frequency becomes necessarily more complicated for languages such as Arabic and other related Semitic languages for which morphemes do not unfold in time with the acoustic signal in contrast with more widely-studied languages such as English. In contrast, Arabic words are formed by noncontiguous morphemes that interleave. Furthermore, frequency studies of Arabic colloquial dialects have been hindered by limited resources which prevent easy calculation of morpheme frequency from an established annotated corpus.


This NSF-funded project enabled the completion of a doctoral dissertation that focused on the dual roles of word frequency and stem morpheme frequency in auditory word recognition. This project involved multiple stages that made separate contributions, most notably the creation of a corpus for an underresourced and understudied variety of Arabic and the completion of four auditory perception experiments.  

 

The corpus was constructed by consolidating and categorizing existing mixed dialectal Arabic data, as well as collecting new data from audio transcription and digitization of printed resources. The auditory lexical decision experiments involved native speakers listening to words and possible but unattested nonce words recorded by a native speaker. For each word a participant heard, they had to respond via button press as quickly as possible and had to choose if the word was a real word of their language or not. The goal of these experiments was to collect reaction time data to see how quickly speakers responded to words which were very frequent, but had comparatively infrequent stems, and vice versa. Furthermore, the words differed with respect to the productivity of their affixes. Results suggest that for productive verbal paradigms of Arabic, both stem and word frequency affect the speed at which speakers recognize words, but for nonproductive verbal paradigms, only the frequency of the word itself determines how quickly a speaker can recognize this word. This has important implications within the discipline as it is among the first studies exhibiting that productivity and frequency interact for languages within the Semitic family. Previous explanations of word recognition for Semitic languages have appealed to the unusual nonconcatenative word structure, but the current study replicates findings for languages such as English and Dutch, meaning that processes of recognition for spoken words are more universal than has been previously proposed.
